Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Quantitative Analysis of Lightning's Multifaced Impact on the Ionosphere
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award addresses fundamental questions about the impact of lightning discharges on the lower ionosphere (60-90 km). Lightning discharges are among the most powerful sources of electrostatic fields and electromagnetic radiation and are known to create significant disturbances in the lower ionosphere. Specifically, two well documented perturbations stem either from direct heating, known as Early/Fast (E/F) events, or from induced bombardment by energetic particles from the radiation belts, known as lightning-induced electron precipitation (LEP). The low ambient electron density of the lower ionosphere precludes direct measurement by standard radar techniques, hence observations of E/F and LEP events are made using remote sensing with Very Low Frequency (VLF, 3-30 kHz) waves from powerful communication transmitters. VLF signals reflect from the lower ionosphere and are perturbed in amplitude and phase when an ionospheric disturbance occurs along the path, thus allowing a form of continuous observation. Efforts to diagnose and understand the physics of disturbances have yielded largely qualitative results to date. This project will bring together two experts in ionospheric and magnetospheric processes to realize the full potential of VLF remote sensing. This project will enhance efforts to forecast navigation and communication outages due to lightning-induced disturbances. Early-career PIs at each institution will lead the project, which will also contribute to the support of several graduate students and a post-doctoral researcher.

Unambiguous determination of the physics of ionospheric disturbances from VLF signal perturbations has been lacking due to the complex nature of VLF signal propagation and also the variability of lightning discharges. In this effort, the challenges to quantifying lightning-ionosphere coupling with VLF remote sensing by introducing the following innovations:
1. Strategic observations of ocean-based lightning and overlapping VLF transmitter paths.
2. Novel polarization and scattered field analysis from amplitude and phase in two channels.
3. Quantifying the role of the lightning source spectrum in the ionospheric disturbance.
4. Improvement of numerical codes for trans-ionospheric propagation and raytracing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The uppermost portion of the atmosphere is known as the ionosphere, it is basically the transition/border zone between the space environment, and the Earth environment. While it critically affects a number of communication systems and satellite signals, we still have a lot to learn about it. One of the main reasons is that is a tough region to make measurements in, being too high for balloons yet too low for satellites. But it flutters around a lot.

It's long been known that radio waves at very low frequencies (VLF), 3-30 kHz, are useful for studying the lower part of the ionosphere, 60-90 km altitude, because these radio waves reflect from the electrically charged plasma. But VLF comes from a limited number of sources, mainly US Navy transmitters for submarine communications, and from lightning. 

In principle we can use these signals to sense the upper atmosphere, since if the ionosphere changes, so do the reflection of VLF waves. But in practice, for a variety of reasons, this is tough to do. Navy transmitters are reliable, continuous, and in known locations, but they?re at just one frequency and there are only a few of them. Lightning, on the other hand, covers many frequencies, and is spread globally, but it emits its energy in only brief bursts, with locations that change depending on where thunderstorms are.

We set out to push forward the science of how to sense the D-region using VLF waves, for both of these types of sources. Each one resulted in a PhD dissertation. For the Navy transmitters, we used a network of VLF receivers across the continental US, and applied a machine learning model, trained by theoretical runs, to nowcast the conditions of the lower ionosphere. The model was able to reproduce the basic daily variation of the ionosphere, as well as track how it changes during a solar flare. It could also be used to nowcast the amplitude and phase at an unspecified site that is not part of the training network. The second effort involved the lightning-generated VLF, known as sferics. This involved a multi-step algorithm to combine these impulsive measurements together, apply theoretical modeling, then use some image-reconstruction theory to reconstruct what the ionosphere looked like.
